title: Will Faraday Future, NextEV, or Atieva start taking orders for electric vehicles in 2016?
preds: No working prototype in sight yet.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
(no change) Just a trip down memory lane regarding what an "order" might entail: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/245097

Back up 25% based on @Dsarin information that the embedded link in the question takes one to the Lucid order ;-) site: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/402684 I haven't submitted a resolution suggestion in a long time. Partly lazy; partly other reasons.

based on the post by @Raisinville,  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/402052, which I consider brilliantly argued and one that deserves to be retained as a terrific example of excellent logic and organization of ideas.   My forecast would be 100%  but, sad to say, I'm not confident in the good judgment of GJO Admins.

Down 25% on this thought. Unless GJO or Mack made a clarification, why would Lucid taking orders be a yes since the question lists three other entities? (Yes, now Atieva is Lucid, but the paper trail might be complicated and a narrow reading of the question might require a tortured explanation to get there.)
There are no actual cars yet. Their factory in Arizona is not built yet. They expect to bring the car to market in 2018. But Lucid Motors is taking orders. Thanks Raisinville!

I think that this question should resolve as "Yes" retroactively to a day or two ago based on  Raisinville's information.  http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/401337 However, I'm making a cynically neutral forecast based on my perception of question resolutions.
Up the other 5%. Why not follow @Raisinville OTOH it should probably be back-dated to yesterday or earlier.

If Lucid calls it an "order"; it must be an order.  
OTOH: "Pricing and additional options to be finalized closer to start of production."

Going down, because I had a response from GJO. They say they're not going to resolve this IFP on the NextEV hypercar at this time due to "insufficient evidence that [NextEV] started taking orders during the question's open period." If they find evidence that NextEV began taking orders during the question period, they may resolve the question retroactively. My thinking is that, if the NextEV hypercar is not going to count, who else would be taking orders before the end of the year? No one else has a car.

This is "not the droid you are looking for," but interesting anyway: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-leeco-idUSKCN12J2MC

Going back to consensus, because GJO will need to determine when NextEV sent the invitations out in order to resolve this question. If resolved, the question will be resolved on that date. Forecasts since then won't count. If not resolved, we continue as if nothing happened. If voided, none of it matters.

I'm not confident in a resolution. NextEV sent out a limited number of invitations to pre-order its forthcoming hypercar. Apparently, the small number of cars on offer were all pre-sold. But we don't know when, and this question opened on 17 May. So some possibilities: 1. GJO cannot determine when the invitations went out, so they void the question.
2. GJO cannot determine when the invitations went out, so they let the question stand unresolved.
3. GJO does not consider private invitations to be "taking orders", so the question is not resolved.
4. GJO determines that invitations went out before 17 May, so they void the question.
5. GJO determines that invitations went out before 17 May, but they leave the question open, as it only applies to 17 May-31 December.
6. GJO determines that invitations went out after 17 May, so that resolves the question. I suspect that GJO will not be able to find out when the invitations went out. The only thing they can do is ask NextEV, and NextEV may not be forthcoming. So the first three possibilities are more likely than the bottom three.

Filed for resolution, based on the seeking alpha news item:
http://seekingalpha.com/article/4012053-nextev-atieva-faraday-future-finalize-development-tesla-competitors Based on all aspects of the question being satisfied:
---NextEv sold 10 or more vehicle, which requires the customer accepting an offer, which creates an order.  Q has no requirement for how many orders must be accepted or for how long they must be accepted.  Based on the Q, taking any orders meets this criterion.
--- The NextEv vehicles are Electric Vehicles.
---It must still be determined if the orders were accepted before or after the question opening date of May 17th.  Two options remain, void the question if the order predates the start of the Q, or a resolution the all aspects of the question have been met.

been thinking more about the NextEV "invitation only" EV car sale.  You can't just open up the doors and let anyone order one of the 10 or 20 coveted EV cars slotted to be built.  What would happen to NextEVs reputation if Donald Trump bought one?  I bet only beautiful famous people have been asked to drive one around.

Are we seeing a shift in the car industry?  Is this a change in American Culture?  The EV industry seems to be modeled after the U.S. Department of Defense Acquisitions Program....That is fork over huge amounts of money and buy something that has not made it off paper.  Oh my.

http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20161013006663/en/NextEV-Officially-Opens-North-American-Headquarters
According to this story, they have been issued a permit to begin testing.  A wise company would not take orders for a vehicle that has not been thoroughly tested, I wouldn't think.   On the other hand, if I go to their office with a large amount of money and say, "I'll take one of those whenever they're ready," and somebody at the company takes the money and makes a note of the conversation (and of course issues a press release), they will have begun taking orders in 2016, even if no vehicles will be delivered until 2017 or 2145 or even never.   It may be time for somebody to clarify what this question means.  Thanks, somebody.

Considering the apparently wide range of plausible interpretations of this question, as evidenced by almost all of the comments so far, this might be a good candidate for withdrawal, or at least very detailed explanation.
Up 25% until there is some clarification. Reminds me of the canal questions (some of which were voided).

Has NextEV already took orders and sold their first batch of cars?  Were the cars sold prior to this question being initiated?  Not sure what to do here? Thanks to @morrel and @praedico for discussing it.  going to 4% (consensus) until something is resolved or clarified. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/349641

https://cleantechnica.com/2016/10/14/atievas-complicated-ev-history-concept-image-name-atvus-unveiling-plans/ "Atieva is slated to unveil its first electric car [the Atvus] . . .  sometime in early December. . . . “Atieva was formed in 2007 by Weng and two co-founders, Bernard Tse and Sheaupyng Lin. The company initially worked to develop batteries and electric drivetrains, filing more than 100 patents and delivering battery packs for electric buses in China. That all changed in 2014, when two Chinese firms invested around $100 million for a nearly 50% stake in the firm. One was BAIC, a Chinese state-owned carmaker, the other LeEco (then called LeTV), a technology company making televisions, smartphones, and electric bikes. Atieva went on a hiring spree and pivoted to developing a complete, autonomous electric car to compete with Elon Musk’s Teslas.” It should be noted here that LeEco has its own electric car concept, has raised $1 billion, and is seemingly backed in large part by the same billionaire backing Faraday Future. . . .  “Vehicle development progressed well through 2015, according to former executives, but there was growing friction among investors. Jia Yueting, the billionaire owner of LeEco, had quietly started his own electric vehicle startup, Faraday Future, in 2014, without informing the Atieva board. Then LeEco announced its own plans to develop a luxury, connected EV called the LeSEE. Meanwhile, BAIC was attempting to get access to Atieva’s battery and drivetrain technology, and wanted to shift the company to focus on Chinese buyers. In November 2015, co-founder Bernard Tse was abruptly ousted as CEO. Then in early 2016, according to former executives, BAIC sold its stake in the company. According to several sources close to Atieva, the buyer of BAIC’s shares was Jia Yueting.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This question doesn't specify that the vehicle must be a "production vehicle", therefore, I think any vehicle that is openly sold would qualify.

How can you sell something without taking orders first?
I'm wondering how GJO defines "high-end":  by price?  Atieva's car is certainly "high end" in my book if price is the criteria!   by functionality/features?  
And how GJO defines "challenge"?  All the articles I have read include analysis of how Atieva's ev (and others in development) challenge Tesla, and conclude the challenge is  significant.

Seems pretty clear.
"Graphs and Stats" shows the Q opened on May 17th, 2016. Seems the only issue  for closing is when NextEv opened to take the first orders:
the Q doesn't seem to require being street legal in the US (per @morrell 's link - not street legal in US), China, or EU; it simply requires taking an order for an EV.     Must be an order somewhere or they wouldn't know who to give the cars to.  China is reportedly the first market.
It is possible that this question was, through inadvertence, not worded optimally.  I suppose therefore that either the Mack people or the GJO staff intend to clarify at the earliest opportunity.

I took a closer look at @Kate 's link and the GJ question.  The Chinese New year falls on 28 Jan 2017 on the US calendar.  The link says "NextEV electric supercar to be unveiled in 2016 and sold in a small number".  If you watch the video she says that the car will be introduced in China only.  The GJ question says "in 2016" I take that to mean a US calendar versus a Chinese calendar?  From a Chinese perspective the car could be released 20 Jan 2017 in China 20 days after this question closed yet still be considered 2016 in China....hmmmm.  Maybe I'm reading too much into it?  Considering 1-7 Oct 2016 is National Day and nobody is working in China this week I'll go a couple points above consensus until I can make more sense of it all.  Anyone want to help me out?

Every time I encounter this question it irritates me more.  I can take orders any time, for anything, for delivery at any time.  If I were a fraudulent alternative automobile firm, I would start taking orders like nobody's business to jack up my investors' confidence.  But the orders really would represent "nobody's business."  In a long and proud line of ill-conceived Qs, this one is very close to the worst. Congratulations.

I'm going to put the odds higher than consensus for these reasons: The question is about taking orders for EVs and must be evaluated with scope sensitivity through the end of the year and sum up the independent probabilities of any of these companies accepting an order for a vehicle. Perhaps NextEV is aiming to be a supplier in the near term but they might take orders for race cars that are non-consumer, all they need is an order or two behind the scenes to a collector perhaps... 3%, if that counts. Could Atieva who has a prototype, accept orders for non-production prototypes already built like the one at the Beijing auto show? That might not fit the definition of the question... but it's an idea.. 2%. Also... TSLA is accepting orders for cars to be produced in 2018 and Atieva has promised to be producing in 2018. After the auto show they might start preorders, who knows? 25%. http://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/atieva-ev-news-rumors-specs-sketch/
They have a TSLA exec and he could want to follow this trend to help raise cash. Taking orders does not have to be consumer orders. Could be a protype. Faraday looks newer but has a concept race car they could sell, thereby "accepting" orders technically. 3%. All told that is 33% probability if all are independent possibilities.

Down 5% on http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/275785 I still suspect that some type of order process might be in their business plan, perhaps sooner rather than later. If nothing else they get some publicity.

A startup could have each LLC raise funds for their perspective goal of the startup?  Not sure what the rules are on that?  I suppose just make sure the LLC is not registered in Delaware? Taking those companies in order: Faraday Future 0%. With no vehicle, it is unlikely to get orders. "Electric vehicle startup Faraday Future doesn’t have a production-ready car yet, but it has said it wants to get to that milestone within two years. The company just broke ground on a $1 billion (£0.7 billion), 3 million-square-foot factory in North Las Vegas in April, and now it wants another factory on Mare Island, a former naval shipyard located in Vallejo, a city north of San Francisco."
http://arstechnica.com/cars/2016/06/faraday-future-wants-to-put-electric-vehicle-factory-on-a-former-naval-shipyard/ NextEV claims in just 1 year it can be in production, but much more likely than the first option. 10% "NextEV, another company in China is working in stealth mode to build up a factory for electric vehicles. Founded just an year ago, NextEV has raised $500M in 4 funding rounds till now. The company focuses on building up a factory in partnership with Nanjing Municipal Government in China. “The plant will have a production capacity annual output of 280,000 units when it goes into operation in the second half of this year, and we will focus on NextEV’s proprietary intellectual technologies such as our world class motors and electronic modules, for the first phase,” NextEV Co-founder & EVP, XPT CEO, Jack Cheng said in the press release.
http://www.startup-buzz.com/nextev-chinese-company-set-take-tesla-near-future/ Atieva doesn't even have a factory and is hiring people currently. 0%.
http://www.monster.com/jobs/c-atieva.aspx However, Qiantu Motor is a far better prospect than any of those also rans. "One of China’s biggest homegrown automotive design firms is taking the plunge into producing its own electric roadster, seeking to stand out from the gaggle of Chinese electric vehicle startups, as well as Tesla Motors Inc., by making a car with materials found more commonly in business jets and mega-yachts. Qiantu Motor, set up by car design company Beijing CH-Auto Technology Co., is currently building a factory in the eastern city of Suzhou to produce the electric car with a carbon-fiber body and aluminum frame, Chairman Lu Qun said in an interview. The sports car, K50, is to debut next year with a starting price of about 700,000 yuan ($106,000), he said, comparable to Tesla’s Model S, which is made of aluminum. The price is about a third of the BMW i8, which also features a lightweight carbon-fiber body that improves performance."
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-05/tesla-challenger-in-china-promises-to-debut-106-000-e-roadster 2017 would have been a much better time to ask. 2016 is far too soon, doesn't give any of these startups a chance.

Not one of the listed firms, but, Quantum Motor is set to produce $106,000 electric, with carbon fiber body and aluminum frame, by year end.

1. How many businesses in general fail within two years? 
2. However, there is a difference between "failure" and "no orders" (i.e. "total failure")
3. Additionally, we are tracking demand for the cars, not sales themselves; therefore, what is the current state of demand in the market for passenger vehicles?
4. What is the state of demand for electric vehicles?
5. Does demand perfectly correlate with a company's ability to start taking orders (would the companies have started taking orders even if there had been no demand)?

They seem to be in the early stages of promoting mission statements, hiring, and breaking ground for factories.  It seems premature for starting to take orders for vehicles in 2016.

Take orders yes, but on the delivery side they will fall short. I am not too bullish on the way the Chinese do business and Faraday is more hype than reality and to make it reality there are more things in the "shady" side of the tree than out there in the open. To prolong the appearance of legitimacy, they will have to take in order this year.
Law suits over oil production methods will start to erode the viability of BIG OIL stocks and MONEY will run to anyone with a plan to rent sunlight.

A lot of Chinese money flying around -to what purpose it's not clear. Faraday Future gives no indication that it will be producing a car in the near future. Neither does Atieva. NextEV's factory will open this year, but the only car it mentions for this year is a super-expensive supercar: https://www.yahoo.com/tech/nextev-unveil-1-million-1-160000164.html So this question will resolve on whether NextEV has a functional enough, fast enough car to begin taking orders by the end of the year. Factories are difficult. Even Tesla doesn't have the hang of them yet. But NextEV only aspires to produce a small number of ultra-luxury roadsters this year. That might work, but I am having trouble seeing it in 6 months. NextEV is starting out with a high-price, low-volume car, as Tesla did. But NextEV's car will be much higher-priced and lower-volume. Will people order a £1,000,000-car that claims to drive like a McLaren P1 or LaFerrari, from a startup, based on a test-drive, when there are only one or two such vehicles in existence? Of course, taking orders doesn't imply that they'll get any. I don't know enough about the manufacture of electric cars (and this one will have a lot more technology built in than a Tesla, which may also be a hurdle) to know if it is feasible to produce a few cars by the end of the year. Tesla did 4 years of prototypes on the Tesla Roadster. Then Tesla produced 3 cars during the first 2 months of production in 2008. NextEV bears watching, but I am not optimistic.
These are young companies. It took Tesla a few years to get off the ground.
Taking orders and delivering them are different!
Starting close with consensus, not sure when orders book will open and don't have enough knowledge to make an informed decision

The number is only this high given the ambiguity of "taking orders": What if a company opens a list but no one wants a car? What if the cars are ordered without a price being set? ...on the latter point, it's hard to imagine orders being taken with no price, and it doesn't seem like these companies will be well-positioned to choose a price soon enough. Staying below consensus.

The main riddle here is whether any of these companies will go with some sales model similar to Tesla's Model 3, taking orders far in advance of car availability.  I don't see any of these companies selling a car this year - Faraday indicates that it will be in two years, Atieva has openings for 49 people at its website, and not low-level positions either.  At this point, their website looks like they're recruiting staff rather than selling a car (IMHO).  NextEV hopes to start production this year - but they sound like a component manufacturer.  References are to a plant manufacturing motors and electronics modules - not sure where the electric vehicle with super car performance comes from but it would need to be built somewhere too.  And again, a website that looks focused on recruiting & VC.

FF does not have sales folks hired, NextEV does not have a Senior Accountants, Atieva does not have marketing folks.   first things first...you gotta have people to take sales orders.  All three companies don't have many... many positions filled yet.  I'm reluctant to answer this question because in my mind an order for an EV means a sales contract versus a "reservation" for a spot to buy.  I bet all three companies will ask for reservations which will cost people a grand or two but there won't be an actual sales order because they won't know how much one will cost until they hire the people to design and build these things.  I'm going low for now.  Anybody got any add ons?  https://jobs.lever.co/faradayfuture

Tesla proved orders can lead production by years.

Faraday Future does not plan to ship until 2017, but even that seems suspect as they have not finished their plant. [http://www.wsj.com/articles/electric-car-maker-faraday-breaks-ground-in-nevada-1460589107] NextEV plans to start shipping its supercar by the end of the year. [http://electrek.co/2016/05/05/nextev-electric-vehicle-factory-china/] Atieva may be merged with Faraday Future in the near future, but they had announced an intended ship date of 2018. [https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/20/faraday-futures-owner-rival-electric-car-startup-atieva-jia-yueting] Put together, only NextEV has plans to ship this year, but the questions is about orders. I doubt that any of the companies could get orders without actual product, though, (even Tesla already had history when they did presales), even if only preliminary models, and if FF doesn't have a plant, that would be difficult if not impossible this year. NextEV's $460 billion plant is scheduled to open the second half of this year, though they claim it will mainly be focused on "motors and electronic modules, for the first phase." [http://www.nextev.com/news] While they state plans to start shipping their supercar, I think it's worth taking with a grain of salt, as does Chelsea Sexton, an EV car advocate and advisor: "I couldn’t find any [reasons to find NextEV credible]. They’re largely an unknown. I have a fair amount of skepticism in general about these start-ups, given that we’ve seen one in the last 20 years of EVs that’s done anything at all." [http://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/transportation/advanced-cars/meet-nextev-the-biggest-ev-startup-youve-never-heard-of] All said, I'm starting pretty low, but will go up if NextEV shows signs of progress towards its end-of-2016 goal.
